Description: A hollow terracotta figure of a cat seated to left on a low plain plinth, with face to front; it wears an amulet on a ribbon. The back is plain. Two-piece mould. Orange-brown Nile silt with some mica. There are minute traces of a white dressing. Some repair-work.
Curator's comments: Boutantin, CdE 81 (2006): 320-2, fig.4 [suggesting Memphis as a provenance, on the basis of a figure from the same mould).

Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Acquired in the Fayum. Roman, first to second century AD. Comparanda: Close, probably same mould-series: Besques 1992: no. D/E 4543, from Middle Egypt, dated late Hellenistic; Petrie et al. 1910: pl. xl:38, from Burnt House A at Memphis, dated c. AD 50, but with Ptolemaic material and also artefacts perhaps as late as the third century AD (the contemporary Burnt House C has a third- to fourth-century north Syrian mortarium: pl. xl:49); Török 1995: no. 282, acquired in Memphis and thought to be a dog. Near: Allard Pierson Museum, Amsterdam, no. 7631; Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, no. 1889.1227, perhaps from Hawara; Fischer 1994: no.1130 (head only), dated second century AD (?) = Vogt 1924: pl. civ:1.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3712)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
